section.title: Registering &rhel; 8 with &rmt;
section.para: Use this procedure to register &rhel; 8 or CentOS Linux 8 with the &rmt; server.

listitem.para: The system you want to register can access the &rmt; server.
You have a &productname; subscription activated in the &scc;.
You have removed the system from any &rh; subscription services it was registered to.

step.para: Disable the &rhla; or CentOS repositories in /etc/yum.repos.d by setting enabled=0 in each .repo file.
Run the rmt-client-setup-res script with the URL of the RMT server as a parameter:
The script performs the following tasks:

listitem.remark: Fails due to conflicts between sles_es-release and centos-gpg-keys, centos-linux-repos, and centos-linux-release. It almost works when I manually add --allowerasing to the rmt-client-setup-res script, but then fails when /usr/share/redhat-release from sles_es-release conflicts with the file from centos-linux-release. It fully works when I also run `rm -r /usr/share/redhat-release` before running the script. I can add these workarounds as steps in this procedure, but it would be better if they (or some equivalent) were just in the script to begin with.

listitem.para: Downloads and runs the rmt-client-setup script, which does the following:
Imports the keys with gpg --import and rpm --import.
Downloads the CA certificate from https://RMT_SERVER/rmt.crt.
Imports the CA certificate to the trust store.
You should see the following output:
listitem.screen:
Installed Products: ------------------------------------------
SLES Expanded Support platform release file (RES/8/x86_64)
Registered
------------------------------------------

listitem.para: You should see RES-8-Updates, RES-AS-8-Updates, and RES-CB-8-Updates.
Run the update command to make sure there are no errors:
